reporting_cycle: The Secretary-General reports to the Security Council within 45 days from the adoption of this resolution
summary:
The Security Council,

Recalling previous resolutions on South Sudan, 

Reaffirms strong commitment to sovereignty, independence, territorial integrity, and national unity of South Sudan.

Welcomes the signing of the “Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan” (the “Agreement”) by President Salva Kiir Mayardit, SPLM/SPLA-IO Chairman Dr. Riek Machar Teny, and other stakeholders, expecting full implementation.

Expresses appreciation for IGAD Ministerial Group’s initiative and IGAD-Plus configuration; urges enhanced international community support during peace implementation.

Reiterates grave alarm at the crisis in South Sudan; acknowledges the Agreement as the first step to reverse the situation.

Calls upon parties to adhere to the permanent ceasefire; intends to update UNMISS mandate to support Agreement implementation.

Condemns human rights violations and abuses, international humanitarian law violations; emphasizes accountability.

Condemns harassment of civil society, humanitarian personnel, and journalists.

Expresses concern over 2.21 million displaced persons; stresses parties’ responsibility for the population’s suffering.

Recalls need for full, safe, and unhindered humanitarian access.

Condemns attacks against humanitarian personnel and facilities.

Expresses appreciation for UNMISS peacekeepers’ actions to protect civilians.
The Security Council,

Condemning the violence and human rights abuses in South Sudan, 

Notes the significant resource and capacity challenges faced by UNMISS in implementing its mandate and appreciates its efforts to support IDPs.

Concerned about reports of war crimes and crimes against humanity, including extrajudicial killings, rape, and use of children in armed conflict.

Stresses the need to end impunity, bring perpetrators to justice, and promote accountability, reconciliation, and healing.

Emphasizes the importance of the rule of law, and notes that individuals responsible for threatening peace, security, or stability may face targeted sanctions.

Recognizes the work of the African Union Commission of Inquiry and welcomes its report.

Condemns hate speech and violence instigating media broadcasts and calls on the Government to take measures to deter such activity.

Urges all parties to promote peace and reconciliation and notes the important role of civil society, faith leaders, women, and youth.

Emphasizes women's empowerment, participation, and human rights.
